o3.stage1_cates:
Classification criteria  
To keep the grouping very coarse, I will look only at the main mathematical “language” or framework that drives the argument.  
• If the solution’s backbone is ordinary trigonometric identities (sum–difference, double-angle, etc.), it belongs to one group.  
• If it replaces the trigonometric problem by a complex-number argument using moduli and arguments, that is a different group.  
• If it reformulates the problem entirely in synthetic geometry (cyclic quadrilaterals, Ptolemy, angle chasing), that is another group.  
Minor variations (e.g. whether one first finds tan (α+β) or matches an answer choice) are not regarded as high-level differences.

Grouping of the five solutions  

Group 1 – Classical trigonometric identities  
Solutions 1, 2, 3  
All three start from the given tangent (or sine) values and manipulate standard trig identities (addition, double-angle, co-function) to arrive at β = π/2 – 2α. The second solution frames it as “trial-and-error with answer choices,” but the work is still pure identity checking, so it belongs with the others.

Group 2 – Complex-number (exponential) method  
Solution 4  
Angles are encoded as arguments of complex numbers (4+3i, 24+7i); multiplication of the complex numbers translates into addition of arguments, giving the relation between α and β.

Group 3 – Synthetic Euclidean geometry  
Solution 5  
Builds a cyclic quadrilateral, invokes Ptolemy’s theorem and angle-chasing in triangles and the circle to obtain the required relation—no trigonometric identities or complex numbers are the main engine.

Thus each solution is placed in exactly one group:  
• Group 1: Solutions 1, 2, 3  
• Group 2: Solution 4  
• Group 3: Solution 5

Classification criteria  
I will separate solutions according to the principal, high-level idea that makes the calculation short:

A. “Expand–then-cancel” in base-10:  
   Rewrite the factors as (multiple of 100 or 10 000) ± 1, distribute, and watch most terms cancel.  
   (Whether one finally evaluates the remaining two small numbers or leaves them symbolic is only an implementation detail.)

B. Sum/Difference of cubes factorisation:  
   Introduce x = 100 and recognise each product as (x ± 1)(x² ∓ x + 1) = x³ ± 1, so their difference is (x³+1) − (x³−1).

C. Modular arithmetic reasoning:  
   Work entirely with remainders to pin down the answer without ever expanding the products.

Grouping of the given solutions

Group A – Expand then cancel  
 Solutions 1, 2, 3  
 All three rewrite the numbers as “(big multiple of 10) ± 1”, distribute the products and cancel the common large term.  
 • Sol-1 uses 10 000 as the base;  
 • Sol-2 uses 100;  
 • Sol-3 actually carries out the expansion to obtain the full six-digit numbers;  
 those differences are only in sub-steps, not in the overarching strategy.

Group B – Cube factorisation  
 Solution 5  
 Introduces x = 100 and uses the identities (x+1)(x²−x+1)=x³+1 and (x−1)(x²+x+1)=x³−1.

Group C – Modular arithmetic  
 Solution 4  
 Determines the result by working modulo 10 and modulo 101, never expanding the products.

Thus each solution fits uniquely into one of three distinct high-level strategy groups:

• Group A: 1, 2, 3  
• Group B: 5  
• Group C: 4

Classification criteria  
To decide whether two solutions belong in the same group we look only at the overarching idea that drives the count of swaps.  
• If the author literally carries out (or symbolically describes) every adjacent swap in order and totals them, it is a “direct-simulation / explicit-procedure” approach.  
• If the author reduces the six-letter task to a smaller version of the same task (or recognises/uses the triangular-number recurrence “moves(n)=moves(n−1)+(n−1)”), it is a “recursive / inductive pattern” approach.  
• If the author recognises that the minimal number of adjacent swaps equals the inversion number of the target permutation and computes that inversion count in one step, it is an “inversion-count / permutation-theory” approach.  

Differences that only concern which letter is moved first, the precise ordering of swaps, or whether the final formula is written out are treated as minor implementation details, not new high-level strategies.

Grouping of the five solutions  

Group 1 – Direct simulation / explicit procedure  
 • Solution 1  
 • Solution 4  
Both list every block of adjacent swaps needed (either moving A to the end or F to the front) and sum those counts directly.

Group 2 – Recursive / inductive pattern (triangular numbers)  
 • Solution 2  
 • Solution 3  
Each observes that after moving one letter it becomes the same problem for a shorter string, leading to the sequence 0,1,3,6,… or to the sum 0+1+2+3+4+5.

Group 3 – Inversion-count / permutation-theory  
 • Solution 5  
Uses the fact that the minimum number of adjacent swaps equals the number of inversions in 654321 and computes that as 1+2+3+4+5=15.

Every solution belongs to exactly one of these three groups.

Classification criteria (high-level only)

A.  “Factor-equation + integer case analysis”  
   1. Combine the given equalities so that each side factors into a product of two integer terms such as  
      (a±c)(b±1)=constant, (b±a)(c±1)=constant, …  
   2. Because the constants are small, list their divisors, assign them to the two factors, and run a finite case check until the admissible triple (a,b,c) is found (often = –9,–12,–8).  
   3. Finish by substituting the triple – or in some variants by using a relation such as  
      ab+bc+ca = (100+87+60) – (a+b+c) – to obtain the requested sum.

   Any solution that follows this overall road map, even if it uses different pairs of equations, different order of the steps, or stops as soon as b is fixed, belongs here.

B.  “Answer-choice elimination / direct option testing”  
   1. Express ab+bc+ca in terms of a+b+c.  
   2. Translate each multiple-choice value into a candidate sum a+b+c.  
   3. Argue that, except for one candidate, no integer triple can satisfy the three original equations, usually by quick trial values or sign/size considerations.  
   4. Verify the lone surviving choice with one explicit triple.

   The distinguishing feature is that the reasoning revolves around eliminating listed answers, not around exhaustively working through factorised equations.

Grouping of the five solutions

Group A  (Factor-equation + integer case analysis)  
• Solution 1  
• Solution 2  
• Solution 3  
• Solution 4  

Group B  (Answer-choice elimination / direct option testing)  
• Solution 5

Classification criteria  

To decide whether two solutions belong to the same group, look only at the top-level strategy they adopt.  
• Strategy A – “Complement / opposite–box argument”:  first notice that the midpoint can lie outside the L only when one point is in the upper square and the other in the right square; compute the probability of that event (usually by symmetry or a small integral) and subtract from 1.  
• Strategy B – Any other fundamentally different idea (e.g. tiling the plane, Monte-Carlo simulation, recursion, etc.).

Two solutions are separated only if one of them uses Strategy B while the other uses Strategy A.  Differences in the way they carry out the integration, how they label the squares, or the symbols they introduce are treated as low-level details and do not create new groups.

Grouping of the five submitted solutions

All five solutions (Solutions 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) use exactly Strategy A:  
• Each starts by taking the complement,  
• notes that the midpoint can be outside the L only when the two points lie in the two squares that meet at the missing corner,  
• evaluates the corresponding probability (by symmetry, by integrating, or by a short geometric argument), and  
• subtracts the result from 1.

Therefore every solution belongs to the same single group.

Final grouping  
Group 1 (Complement / opposite–box argument):  Solutions 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

Classification criteria  
To keep the grouping strictly high-level, I shall look only at the main strategy that turns the original arrangement problem into something easier to count.  
• Group A – “Subset‐of-first-pass” counting:  Count every way to decide which cards (or positions) are collected on the first pass and then correct for the illegal case where all 13 are taken at once.  The essential step is “choose any subset of the 13 positions, giving 2¹³ choices, then subtract the 14 bad ones (or, equivalently, sum (13 choose k)–1 over k)”.  
• Group B – Recurrence on n:  Build the answer for n cards from the answer for n–1 cards by analyzing the first entry, leading to a recurrence Aₙ = Aₙ₋₁ + (something).  
• Group C – Empirical pattern spotting:  List small cases, guess the general formula 2ⁿ – n – 1 and quote it for n = 13 without a separate counting argument.

Grouping of the five solutions  
Group A (Subset-of-first-pass enumeration):  Solutions 1, 2, 5  
 • All three explicitly (or after a short summation) count 2¹³ arrangements and subtract the 14 with only one pass; Solution 2 dresses it up with a hockey-stick identity, but the overarching idea is the same.

Group B (Recurrence):  Solution 3  
 • The core step is relating Aₙ to Aₙ₋₁ by considering the first card, giving a recurrence that is then summed.

Group C (Empirical pattern):  Solution 4  
 • The answer is obtained by listing small n, spotting the sequence 2ⁿ – n – 1 and extrapolating.

Each solution belongs to exactly one of these three high-level groups.

Classification criteria  
To decide whether two solutions belong in the same group, look only at the main strategy they use to identify the closed-form of  
f(a)=|a−2−√(a−1)² | for a<0.

1. Algebraic simplification group  
   • Central idea: Manipulate the expression symbolically, apply the definition of | · |, and simplify until the absolute value disappears, yielding the formula directly.

2. Numerical-sampling / answer-matching group  
   • Central idea: Do not simplify the expression fully; instead evaluate it at one or more conveniently chosen a–values and use those numerical results—together with the multiple-choice list or an assumption of linearity—to pick or reconstruct the correct formula.

Solutions placed in the same group may differ in minor details (how many points they test, whether they mention continuity, etc.), but they share the same overarching tactic.

Grouping of the five solutions

Group 1 – Algebraic simplification  
 • Solution 1  
 • Solution 4  
Both immediately replace √(a−1)² with |a−1|, use a<0 to rewrite |a−1| as 1−a, and then simplify |2a−3| to 3−2a.

Group 2 – Numerical sampling / answer matching  
 • Solution 2  
 • Solution 3  
 • Solution 5  
– Solution 2 evaluates the expression at a single test point (a=−1) and matches that number to the multiple-choice list.  
– Solution 3 reasons that the function must be linear or constant, then checks two values (a=0 and a=−1000) to rule out the constant and pick the linear choice.  
– Solution 5 computes the value at two points (a=−1 and a=−2), treats the results as points on a line, and reconstructs the linear formula.  

Although their details vary, all three rely on plugging in numerical values rather than on a direct symbolic simplification; hence they belong together.

Every solution is placed in exactly one of the two high-level groups, and all five solutions are accounted for.

Classification criteria  
I will distinguish the solutions according to the high-level strategy they use to pass from the polynomial to the desired product (the new volume).

Criterion A – “Vieta/symmetric–sum route”:  
The solver keeps the roots symbolic, invokes Vieta’s relations (possibly after a linear shift), and obtains the product (a+2)(b+2)(c+2) from the elementary symmetric sums, without ever needing the explicit numerical roots.

Criterion B – “Explicit-factorisation/individual-roots route”:  
The solver actually finds every root of the cubic—either by outright factoring or by using the Rational Root Theorem and division—and then multiplies the shifted numerical roots.

A solution is placed in a separate group only if it switches between these two overarching strategies; differences such as how the factorisation is achieved or how the Vieta identities are written are not considered high-level distinctions.

Grouping of the five given solutions

Group 1 – Vieta/symmetric-sum route  
Solutions 1, 4, 5  
• Sols 1 and 5 expand (p+2)(q+2)(r+2) and substitute the three symmetric sums from Vieta.  
• Sol 4 shifts the polynomial to P(x−2) so that the desired product is simply the product of the new roots, then uses Vieta’s “constant term ÷ leading coefficient” rule.  
All three rely solely on Vieta and never compute the individual roots.

Group 2 – Explicit-factorisation/individual-roots route  
Solutions 2, 3  
• Sol 2 directly factors the cubic.  
• Sol 3 first finds the rational root 3, performs polynomial division, then factors the quadratic remainder.  
Both obtain each root numerically and multiply (root + 2).

Each solution is thus assigned to exactly one group, and the two groups reflect completely distinct high-level strategies.

Classification criteria  
I will group solutions according to the single, high-level plan they use to obtain the exposed surface area.

A. “Side-faces vs. horizontal-faces” decomposition  
 • First compute the total lateral (side) area 4 ∑ n².  
 • Then compute the horizontal contribution by observing that the area visible when you look straight down equals the area of the base cube, and add the base face.  
Typical structure: 4 ∑ n²  +  base bottom  +  base-on-top view.  

B. “Total surface minus overlaps”  
 • Start with the full 6 ∑ n² surface area of all seven cubes taken separately.  
 • Subtract the areas of faces that are hidden where two consecutive cubes touch (2 ∑ n² for n = 1 … 6).  

C. “Face-count per cube”  
 • Decide how many faces of each individual cube are exposed (6, 5 or 4, depending on its position).  
 • Add the appropriate multiple of n² for each cube, possibly using a telescoping trick for the horizontal faces.  

Grouping of the given solutions  

Group A (side vs. horizontal decomposition): Solutions 1 and 5  
Group B (total minus overlaps): Solution 2  
Group C (face-count per cube): Solutions 3 and 4

Each solution appears in exactly one group and the groups differ only by the high-level strategy described above.

Classification criteria  
To decide whether two solutions belong in the same group, look only at the over-arching line of attack they use.  
Two solutions go into the ​same​ group when, at a bird’s-eye level, they do the same three things in the same order:

1.  For every possible “reroll choice’’ (0, 1, 2, 3 dice) they first compute the probability of eventually ending with a total of 7, expressed as a simple closed form that depends on the visible dice.  
2.  They then compare those probabilities for the four choices to decide what the *optimal* move is for each initial triple.  
3.  Finally, after the optimal move has been identified, they count all initial triples for which “reroll exactly two dice’’ is optimal and divide by 216.

If a solution follows some different master plan—e.g. simulation, dynamic programming, or a martingale argument—then it would belong in a different group.  Mere differences in how the probabilities are derived (tables vs. a formula, wording, or notation) are *not* high-level differences.

Grouping of the five solutions

Group A “Probability-comparison decision tree’’  
Overarching strategy: steps 1–2–3 described above.  
The solutions evaluate P(win | reroll k) for k = 0,1,2,3, compare them (usually via the formula (6–a)/36, 1/6, and 5/72), decide when the k = 2 option is optimal, and then count those initial rolls.

• Solution 1  
• Solution 2  
• Solution 3  
• Solution 4  
• Solution 5  

Because every one of the five solutions uses exactly this high-level framework, they all fall into the same group.

There are therefore no other distinct high-level approaches present, and we end up with a single group containing all five solutions.
